ARTICLE 3.03 UNSAFE BUILDINGS*
Sec. 3.03.001 Statement of policy
All buildings which are determined to be unsafe, unsanitary, or not provided with adequate egress, or which
constitute a fire hazard, or which in relation to existing use constitute a hazard to safety or health by reason of
inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence, or abandonment, are unsafe buildings. These unsafe
buildings are hereby declared illegal and shall be abated by repair and rehabilitation or by demolition in
accordance with the following procedures. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I)
Sec. 3.03.002 Minimum standards for use and occupancy
An owner of a building or structure that fails to comply with the requirements of the codes and the regulations
herein shall be subject to abatement:
(1) When the exterior walls or other vertical structural members of said building, dwelling or
structure list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing though the center of gravity
does not fit inside the middle 1/3 of the base;
(2) Whenever the building, dwelling, or structure, exclusive of the foundation, shows:
(A) More then 50% damage or deterioration of its supporting member or members; or
(B) 50% damage or deterioration of its nonsupporting members, enclosing or outside walls or
coverings;
(3) Whenever the building, dwelling or structure has improperly distributed loads upon the
foundation or roofs or when said foundation or roofs are overloaded or have insufficient strength to
be reasonably safe for the purpose used, to the general public or possible occupants;
(4) Regardless of structural condition, remains unoccupied and unsecured so as to become:
(A) An attractive nuisance to children;
(B) A harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons; or
(C) As to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose of committing unlawful or immoral
acts;
(5) Is manifestly unsafe and dangerous to the life, safety, or general health and welfare of possible
occupants or the general public;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 46/418
(6) Intended to be used for habitation, is determined by the building standards and renewal board
(see section 3.03.004) to be unsanitary, unfit for human habitation or in such a condition that is likely
to cause sickness or disease;
(7) Has inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic; or if the door, aisle, passageway,
stairway or other means of exit is not of sufficient width or size; or if it is not arranged to provide
safe and adequate means of exit for said purposes;
(8) Any portion thereof is likely to fall, to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and
thereby injure person or damage property;
(9) Any portion thereof is likely to partially or completely collapse because of:
(A) Dilapidation, deterioration or decay;
(B) Faulty construction;
(C) The removal, movement or inability of any portion of the ground necessary for the
purpose of supporting such building;
(D) The deterioration, decay or inadequacy of its foundation; or
(E) Any other cause;
(10) Has a floor, exterior wall or roof with holes, cracks or loose, rotten, warped or protruding
boards therein so as not to give reasonable protection to any occupants or possible occupants from
weather elements or danger of collapse;
(11) Has interior walls or ceiling with holes, cracks, loose plaster, defective materials, or structural
deterioration to the extent that it is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is being used or so
as not to give reasonable protection to any occupants from danger of collapse or fire;
(12) Because of obsolescence, dilapidated condition, deterioration, damage, inadequate exits, lack
of sufficient fire-resistive construction, faulty electric wiring, gas connections or heating apparatus,
or other cause, is determined by the chief building official to be a fire hazard;
(13) Whenever any portion of said building, dwelling, or structure remains on a site after the
demolition or destruction of the building, dwelling, or structure, or portion thereof, [and is] an
attractive nuisance to children or hazard to the public or their property.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 1.00)
Sec. 3.03.003 Duties of chief building official
The chief building official shall have the following responsibilities:
(1) As a first order of business, the chief building official shall undertake a window survey for the
purpose of identifying abandoned and dilapidated buildings and structures;
(2) Aggressively inspect all abandoned or unoccupied buildings or structures which may come to
his attention as a violation of this article;
(3) Upon completion of the survey, the chief building official shall report his findings to the
director of planning and community development, the building standards and renewal board and the
city commission;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 47/418
(4) Compile and maintain a current inventory of unsafe buildings which may be in violation of this
article;
(5) Issue a notice of complaint and intent to abate under the procedures set out herein; and
(6) File complaints with the building standards and renewal board.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 2.00)
Sec. 3.03.004 Building standards and renewal board established
(a) There is hereby created a building standards and renewal board (BSRB) to serve at the pleasure of the city
commission. The BSRB shall consist of five (5) persons. The BSRB shall be composed of three members from
the general public and two members from any facet of the construction industry.
(b) The mayor shall nominate and the city commission shall ratify the appointment of members of the BSRB.
Three of the original appointees shall serve two-year terms; the remaining two appointees shall serve three years.
The initial terms shall be determined by lot. Thereafter, all appointments shall be for three-year terms, based on a
calendar year. An appointee to the BSRB shall forfeit his appointment upon his failure to attend three
consecutive meetings in a calendar year.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 3.00)
Sec. 3.03.005 Abatement required
The BSRB shall require the vacation, relocation of occupants, securing, repair, removal, or demolition of a
building that is:
(1) Dilapidated, substandard, or unfit for human habitation or a hazard to the public health, safety,
and welfare;
(2) Unoccupied by its owners, lessees, or other invitees and is unsecured from unauthorized entry
to the extent that it could be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of
harborage or could be entered or used by children, regardless of its structural condition; or
(3) Boarded up, fenced, or otherwise secured in any manner if:
(A) The building constitutes a danger to the public even though secured from entry; or
(B) The means used to secure the building are inadequate to prevent unauthorized entry or
use of the building.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 4.00)
Sec. 3.03.006 First notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement
(a) Upon the determination by the chief building official that any building, structure or portion fails to meet
the minimum standards, he shall give the owner, agent or person in control or possession of such building or
structure, and all his holders of record, a written notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement by certified or
registered mail.
(b) The notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement shall:
(1) Identify the building and the property on which it is located, which is not required to be a legal
description;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 48/418
(2) Identify with specificity each of the defects or deficits in the building or structure which cause
the building to fail to meet the minimum standards;
(3) State the date on which the chief building official proposes to submit his complaint and intent
to seek abatement to the BSRB;
(4) Invite the owner, agent or person having control or possession of such building or structure,
and all of his holders of record, to attempt an informal resolution of the matter;
(5) Contain in bold letters the following language: “FAILURE TO CONTACT THE
UNDERSIGNED PUBLIC OFFICIAL IN TEN DAYS FROM THE DATE OF THIS LETTER MAY
RESULT IN THE WAIVER OF YOUR RIGHT TO INFORMALLY RESOLVE THIS COMPLAINT
PRIOR TO THE FILING OF FORMAL PROCEEDINGS TO ABATE.”
(6) State that the owner, agent or person in control or possession of such building or structure shall
have the right to request a hearing before the BSRB concerning abatement of violations without first
attempting informal resolution of the matter. This request shall be communicated in writing to the
chief building official not later than the 10th day after receipt of the notice.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 5.00)
Sec. 3.03.007 Second notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement
If the owner does not contact the chief building official within ten days or if no informal resolution is agreed to
within 30 days from the date the first notice is given, the chief building official shall give a second notice of
complaint and intent to seek abatement by certified mail return receipt requested, hereinafter to be referred to as
the “second notice,” to the owner or agent or person in control over such building or structure and all lienholders
of record of said property involved, stating that a complaint has been filed with the BSRB and that a hearing
shall be held by said board to allow the owner, in person or through his attorney, to respond to the notice. A copy
of the “second notice” shall be filed with BSRB and shall constitute a complaint. Said hearing shall be held more
than ten (10) days after mailing of said second notice. The date, time and place for said hearing shall be
contained in the second notice letter. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 6.00)
Sec. 3.03.008 Published notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement
If the address of the owner or owner's agent is unknown, the notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement
shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county once a week for two (2) consecutive
weeks, with an affidavit being returned to the chief building official of the city showing publication of same. If
within ten (10) days from the date the notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement is published on the
second week, the owner or owner's agent does not comply with the requirements of the original notice, a second
notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county once a week for two (2) consecutive
weeks, with an affidavit being returned to the chief building official of the city showing publication of same. On
publication of the second notice, the city official shall file a written complaint with the BSRB. The date for the
hearing in said published second notice shall be more than ten (10) days after the last day of the second week of
publication of the second notice. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 7.00)
Sec. 3.03.009 Title search
To determine the ownership of interests, liens or claims on the property, the chief building official shall
diligently search the following records:
(1) County real property records of the county in which the building is located;
(2) Appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the building is located;
(3) Records of the secretary of state;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 49/418
(4) Assumed name records of the county in which the building is located;
(5) Tax records of the city; and
(6) Utility records of the city.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 8.00)
Sec. 3.03.010 Informal resolution of complaints
(a) If the record owner of the property, or his agent, on which the building or structure is located timely
responds to the notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement, the chief building official shall have the
discretion to do the following:
(1) Enter into a voluntary abatement agreement providing for the repair/rehabilitation of the
building or structure or removal/demolition of the building or structure or portion thereof for a period
of time not to exceed 90 days;
(2) Modify and reissue the notice of complaint and intent to seek abatement and submit it to the
BSRB; or
(3) Withdraw the notice altogether.
(b) The chief building official's informal resolution of all complaints shall be submitted to the BSRB. It shall
be incorporated into an order of the BSRB and a record made.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 9.00)
Sec. 3.03.011 Responsibilities of building standards and renewal board
The BSRB shall have the following responsibilities and abide by the following procedures:
(1) Prior to initiating proceedings on a complaint, the chairman of the BSRB shall inquire of each
BSRB member whether the member knows of a conflict or potential conflict of interest with respect
to the complaint to be adjudicated. A member with a conflict or potential conflict shall not sit in
adjudication of the complaint. The BSRB shall refer all legal questions to the city attorney.
(2) The BSRB shall have no power to incur any expense for the demolition of any building or
structure, or portion thereof, but in appropriate cases may recommend action to the city commission.
(3) The BSRB shall have the power to refer the adjudicated claim to the municipal court for the
purpose of imposing a fine in connection with any abatement order.
(4) A hearing under this section may be held by the municipal court or a hearings officer
designated by the BSRB, but any abatement order shall be issued solely by the BSRB.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 10.00)
Sec. 3.03.012 Record of hearing
The chairman shall call out the complaint number and identify for the record all persons present at the hearing
having an interest in the property, the subject of the complaint, the attorneys and the witnesses. All documentary
evidence shall be marked and become part of the record. A party to a complaint hearing may call witnesses,
including expert witnesses. An audio, video or stenographic record shall be made of all proceedings before the
BSRB. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 11.00)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 50/418
Sec. 3.03.013 Burden of proof at hearing
In all cases presented to the BSRB, the chief building official shall have the burden of proving, by the greater
weight of the evidence, that:
(1) The building or structure does not conform to one or more of the minimum standards;
(2) The plan proposed by the chief building official to abate the violations is an efficient and
reasonable one; or
(3) Demolition of the building or structure is the only way of abating the unsafe condition.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 12.00)
Sec. 3.03.014 Conduct of hearing
The hearing shall be conducted by the presiding officer of the BSRB and shall hear evidence presented by the
chief building official and any other witnesses on behalf of the city in support of the complaint. The owner, or
his attorney, shall have the right to cross-examine the city's witnesses and to call witnesses and present evidence
in defense. Each side may also present rebuttal evidence. At the close of the evidence, the BSRB shall make its
determination as whether or not a building, dwelling, or structure is in violation of this regulation. If the BSRB
determines that a violation exists, the BSRB shall further determine what corrective action shall be necessary to
abate this violation and shall order the owner of the property to take such corrective action. (1999 Unified
General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 13.00)
Sec. 3.03.015 Abatement order
(a) After the public hearing, if a building is found in violation, the BSRB may order that the building be
vacated, secured, repaired, removed, or demolished by the owner within 30 days or a reasonable time as
determined by the BSRB. The BSRB also may order that the occupants be relocated within a reasonable time.
(b) If the BSRB allows the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than 30 days to repair, remove, or demolish
the building, the BSRB shall establish specific time schedules for the commencement and performance of the
work and shall require the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee to secure the property in a reasonable manner from
unauthorized entry while the work is being performed.
(c) The BSRB may not allow the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than 90 days to repair, remove, or
demolish the building or fully perform all work required to comply with the order unless the owner, lienholder,
or mortgagee:
(1) Submits a detailed plan and time schedule for the work at the hearing; and
(2) Establishes at the hearing that the work cannot reasonably be completed within 90 days
because of the scope and complexity of the work.
(d) If the BSRB allows the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee more than 90 days to complete any part of the
work required to repair, remove, or demolish the building, the BSRB shall require the owner, lienholder, or
mortgagee to regularly submit progress reports to the city to demonstrate that the owner, lienholder, or
mortgagee has complied with the time schedules established for commencement and performance of the work.
The order may require that the owner, lienholder, or mortgagee appear before the hearing official or the hearing
official's designee to demonstrate compliance with the time schedules.
(e) The owner, lienholder, or mortgagee has the burden of proof to demonstrate the scope of any work that
may be required to comply with these regulations and the time it will take to reasonably perform the work.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 51/418
(f) As an alternative to the procedure prescribed by this section, the city may make a diligent effort to discover
each mortgagee and lienholder before conducting the public hearing and may give them a notice of and an
opportunity to comment at the hearing. In addition, the city may file notice of the hearing in the official public
records of real property in the county in which the property is located. The notice must contain the name and
address of the owner of the affected property if that information can be determined, a legal description of the
affected property, and a description of the hearing. The filing of the notice is binding on subsequent grantees,
lienholders, or other transferees of an interest in the property who acquire such interest after the filing of the
notice, and constitutes notice of the hearing on any subsequent recipient of any interest in the property who
acquires such interest after the filing of the notice. If the city operates under this subsection, the order issued by
the city may specify a reasonable time as provided by this section for the building to be vacated, secured,
repaired, removed, or demolished by the owner or for the occupants to be relocated by the owner and an
additional reasonable time as provided by this section for the ordered action to be taken by any of the
mortgagees or lienholders in the event the owner fails to comply with the order within the time provided for
action by the owner. Under this subsection, the city is not required to furnish any notice to a mortgagee or
lienholder other than a copy of the order in the event the owner fails to timely take the ordered action.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 14.00)
Sec. 3.03.016 Failure to comply with order; securing of building
(a) If the building is not vacated, secured, repaired, removed, or demolished, or the occupants are not
relocated, within the allotted time, the BSRB may request that the city vacate, secure, remove, or demolish the
building or relocate the occupants at its own expense.
(b) The BSRB may secure a building if the abatement order is not complied with and the BSRB determines
the building or structure:
(1) Violates the minimum standards; and
(2) Is unoccupied or is occupied only by persons who do not have a right of possession to the
building.
(c) Before the 11th day after the date the building is secured, the BSRB shall give notice to the owner by:
(1) Personally serving the owner with written notice; or
(2) Depositing the notice in the U.S. mail addressed to the owner at the owner's post office address.
(d) If the owner is unknown, the BSRB shall give notice by publishing the notice at least twice within a 10-
day period in a newspaper of general circulation in the county if personal service cannot be obtained and the
owner's post office address is unknown, or posting the notice on or near the front door of the building if personal
service cannot be obtained and the owner's post office address is unknown.
(e) The notice must contain:
(1) An identification, which is not required to be a legal description, of the building and the
property on which it is located;
(2) A statement that the BSRB will secure or has secured, as the case may be, the building; and
(3) An explanation of the owner's entitlement to request a hearing about any matter relating to the
BSRB's securing of the building.
(f) The BSRB shall conduct a hearing at which the owner may testify or present witnesses or written
information about any matter relating to the BSRB's securing of the building if, within 30 days after the date the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 52/418
BSRB secures the building, the owner files with the BSRB a written request for the hearing. The BSRB shall
conduct the hearing within 20 days after the date the request is filed.
(g) If the owner does not take the ordered action within the allotted time, the BSRB shall make a diligent
effort to discover each mortgagee and lienholder having an interest in the building or in the property on which
the building is located. The BSRB shall send to each identified mortgagee and lienholder a notice containing:
(1) A description of the violation of municipal standards that is present at the building; and
(2) A statement that the BSRB will vacate, secure, remove, or demolish the building or relocate the
occupants of the building if the ordered action is not taken within a reasonable time.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 15.00)
Sec. 3.03.017 Written decision required
A determination shall not be construed to have been made until it has been put into the form of a written
decision and reviewed by the board for clarification and verification of intent and purpose. Such review shall be
deemed to be completed upon said written form being signed by the board's chairman or other board member
and attested to by the recording secretary. Said written form shall include the following:
(1) The date of the hearing;
(2) The name and address of the owner, if known;
(3) The legal description of the property (in the form of an actual address or a physical location);
(4) The specific date by which the board's determination must be fully and completely complied
with;
(5) The determination of the board, including action to be taken by owner; and
(6) The decision of the board as per the motion made, whom made by, whom seconded by, and
votes in favor of and against said motion.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 16.00)
Sec. 3.03.018 Determination to include specific time for compliance
If a determination is made by the board requiring that the owner abate the nuisance or that he demolish the
building or structure, such determination shall include a reference to a specific date by which such abatement or
demolition is to be completed. Said date shall be such as to provide reasonable time for full compliance with the
board's determination. Such time, however, shall be at the total discretion of the BSRB, and shall not be
overridden by the time allotted by any building permit required and/or issued for the process of complying with
the board's determination. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 17.00)
Sec. 3.03.019 Applicability of determination to subsequent owners
The board's determination, including the allotted time for compliance with such determination, shall bind any
subsequent owner(s) of subject property if said property is sold prior to expiration of the allotted time. (1999
Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 18.00)
Sec. 3.03.020 Mailing of notice of decision; application for rehearing
(a) Notice of the decision of the board upon original hearing shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt
requested, within seven (7) days of the hearing, to the owner and to any lienholder or mortgagee of the building
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 53/418
or the subject property, stating in said letter that said owner has ten (10) days from the date of postmark of said
letter to apply for a rehearing (said rehearing to be set by the board within ten (10) days of the application date,
but to be held more than ten (10) days from said application date).
(b) The BSRB shall use its best efforts to determine the identity and address of any owner, lienholder, or
mortgagee of the building. If a notice is mailed and the U.S. Postal Service returns the notice as “refused” or
“unclaimed,” the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice shall be deemed as delivered.
(c) Certified mail notice or actual personal notice of the date for rehearing, if applied for, will be served upon
the owner.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 19.00)
Sec. 3.03.021 Finality of decision; public notice of decision
The decision of the board upon original hearing shall be final after the tenth day after said decision has been
reached, if no motion for rehearing has been applied for. The decision of the board shall be published once in a
newspaper of general circulation if the certified mail letter containing the decision of the board is refused for any
reason, or if the owner's address is unknown. Additionally, a copy of said notice letter shall be kept publicly
posted in the office of the chief building official for two (2) weeks after the decision on original hearing of the
board has been reached, and an additional copy shall be posted, for the same two (2) weeks, upon the city
bulletin board of the city hall. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 20.00)
Sec. 3.03.022 Failure to appear at hearing
If the owner or his attorney or his agent fails to appear at the original hearing of the board, or at the rehearing or
special hearing after having applied for same, the original hearing, rehearing, or special hearing shall be deemed
to have waived by the owner. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 21.00)
Sec. 3.03.023 Decision upon rehearing
Upon rehearing, if the board reaches the same decision as in its original hearing, the decision shall become final
upon such decision being reached by a majority of said board. Upon reaching the same said decision, the board
may make an allowance for elapsed time. Should the board reach a different decision or grant an extension of
time, such determination shall be deemed to be a final decision upon such decision being reached by a majority
of said board. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 22.00)
Sec. 3.03.024 Trial de novo
(a) After said decision becomes final, the owner shall have fifteen (15) days to file suit for a trial de novo in a
court of appropriate jurisdiction. Failing to do so within said fifteen (15) days, the city will consider the owner to
be in agreement with the finding of the BSRB and that said owner waives any judicial action since said time is a
reasonable time for filing said suit.
(b) If the owner has failed to abate the condition or demolish the structure within the time specified in the
final decision of the board, the city will move to abate the condition or demolish the structure and assess the cost
of proceeding, including publication expenses and/or certification of mail expenses and/or demolition expenses,
against said property, and affix a lien thereto. Said lien shall be superior to all other liens except tax liens.
Service of process upon an officer of the city naming the city as a party in a judicial determination of said
condition will automatically suspend action on behalf of the city in abating said condition.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 23.00)
Sec. 3.03.025 Statement of city's expenses
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 54/418
Whenever any work is done or improvements are made by the city under the provisions hereof, the chief
building official, on behalf of the city, shall file a statement of the expenses incurred thereby with the county
clerk. Such statement shall give the amount of such expenses and the date or dates on which the work was done
or the improvements were made. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 24.00)
Sec. 3.03.026 Lien for city's expenses
After the statement is filed, the city shall have a privileged lien on the lot or real estate upon which the work was
done or improvements made to secure the expense thereof. Such liens shall be second only to tax liens and liens
for street improvements. For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and
foreclosures of the lien may be had in the name of the city, and the statement of expenses, or a certified copy,
shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work or improvements. (1999 Unified General Code,
ch. 9, art. I, sec. 25.00)
Sec. 3.03.027 Alternative procedure; civil penalty
(a) In addition to any authority exercised by the BSRB, after the expiration of the time allotted under the
abatement order, the city may:
(1) Repair the building at the expense of the municipality and assess the expenses on the land on
which the building stands or to which it is attached and may provide for that assessment, the mode
and manner of giving notice, and the means of recovering the repair expenses.
(2) Assess a civil penalty against the property owner for failure to repair, remove, or demolish the
building and provide for that assessment, the mode and manner of giving notice, and the means of
recovering the assessment.
(b) The repair of a building may be made only to the extent necessary to bring the building into compliance
with the minimum standards and only if the building is a residential building with 10 or fewer dwelling units.
The repairs may not improve the building to the extent that the building exceeds minimum housing standards.
(c) The city shall impose a lien against the land on which the building stands or stood, unless it is a homestead
as protected by the state constitution, to secure the payment of the repair, removal, or demolition expenses or the
civil penalty. Promptly after the imposition of the lien, the municipality must file for record, in recordable form,
in the office of the county clerk of the county in which the land is located, a written notice of the imposition of
the lien. The notice must contain a legal description of the land.
(d) Except as provided by Texas Local Government Code section 214.001, the city's lien to secure the
payment of a civil penalty or the costs of repairs, removal, or demolition is inferior to any previously recorded
bona fide mortgage lien attached to the real property to which the municipality's lien attaches if the mortgage
lien was filed for record in the office of the county clerk of the county in which the real property is located
before the date the civil penalty is assessed or the repair, removal, or demolition is begun by the municipality.
The municipality's lien is superior to all other previously recorded judgment liens.
(e) Any civil penalty or other assessment imposed accrues interest at the rate of 10 percent a year from the
date of the assessment until paid in full.
(f) The city's right to the assessment lien may not be transferred to third parties.
(g) In any judicial proceeding regarding enforcement of municipal rights, the prevailing party is entitled to
recover reasonable attorney's fees from the nonprevailing party.
(h) A lien acquired under this section by a municipality for repair expenses may not be foreclosed if the
property on which the repairs were made is occupied as a residential homestead by a person 65 years of age or
older.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 55/418
(i) [An assessment of a civil penalty] Is final and binding and constitutes prima facie evidence of the penalty
in any suit brought by a municipality in a court of competent jurisdiction for a final judgment in accordance with
the assessed penalty.
(j) To enforce a civil penalty under this article, the city secretary must file with the district clerk of the county
a certified copy of an order issued under subsection (i) stating the amount and duration of the penalty. No other
proof is required for a district court to enter a final judgment on the penalty.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 9, art. I, sec. 26.00)
ARTICLE 3.04 MANUFACTURED HOMES, MOBILE HOMES AND TRAVEL TRAILERS*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 3.04.001 Purpose
To improve the general welfare and safety of owners of manufactured housing as well as of owners of standard
housing by adopting these regulations, the city seeks:
(1) The eventual elimination of mobile homes and manufactured homes from individual lots in
conventional single-family residential neighborhoods;
(2) The development of separately designated areas for manufactured housing to permit
compatibility; and
(3) Coordination with state regulatory agencies with preemptive jurisdiction over regulation of the
manufacture and installation of manufactured housing.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I)
Sec. 3.04.002 Violations
(a) No person shall permit, or cause to be permitted, the installation of, and no person shall install, a mobile
home within the corporate limits of the city.
(b) No person shall permit, or cause to be permitted, the installation of, and no person shall install, a HUDcode
manufactured home within the corporate limits of the city without a permit as required by these
regulations.
(c) It shall be a violation of these regulations for a person designated as a registrar to fail to register
manufactured homes and travel trailers or file the register as required by section 3.04.128.
(d) No alteration of any type shall be permitted on a mobile home or manufactured home except a
manufactured home placed in an existing mobile home subdivision or park prior to 1994.
(e) A person shall not occupy a travel trailer or recreational vehicle for residential use.
(f) A person shall not rent or lease a travel trailer or recreational vehicle for residential use.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. VI, sec. 6.00)
Sec. 3.04.003 Occupancy of travel trailers or recreational vehicles
(a) Except as hereinafter expressly provided, travel trailers and recreational vehicles shall not be occupied for
residential uses.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 56/418
(b) A person shall not connect a travel trailer or recreational vehicle to water, sewer or electrical services
unless the travel trailer or recreational vehicle is located in a travel trailer or recreational vehicle park duly
licensed pursuant to the provisions of these regulations.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.00)
Sec. 3.04.004 Mobile homes prohibited
The installation of a mobile home for use or occupancy within the corporate limits of the city as a residential
dwelling is hereby strictly prohibited. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.01)
State law reference–Authority to prohibit installation of mobile homes used for residences, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, sec.
1201.008.
Sec. 3.04.005 Manufactured homes restricted
The installation of a HUD-code manufactured home for use or occupancy within the corporate limits of the city
as a residential dwelling is hereby strictly prohibited except as expressly provided. (1999 Unified General Code,
ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.02)
Sec. 3.04.006 Permitted locations for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles
(a) No manufactured home or travel trailer shall be used or occupied on any tract of land within the corporate
limits of the city except within a manufactured home subdivision or park.
(b) No recreational vehicle or travel trailer shall be used or occupied in the city except within a travel trailer
park or subdivision approved by the city and conforming to the standards and requirements set forth herein.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.03)
Sec. 3.04.007 Nonconforming uses
(a) Any manufactured home or mobile home used or occupied within the corporate limits of the city prior to
December 7, 1994 (the passage of this article) shall be considered a nonconforming use. A mobile home that is
removed from a property that is not a park or a subdivision authorized under the 1994 manufactured home
regulations shall not be replaced.
(b) A mobile home that is removed from a property that is a park or a subdivision authorized prior to
December 7, 1994, may only be replaced by a HUD-code manufactured home.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.04)
Sec. 3.04.008 Installation of manufactured homes
(a) Upon application, the installation of a HUD-code manufactured home shall be permitted as a residential
dwelling only as follows:
(1) An application to install a new HUD-code manufactured home for use or occupancy within the
city shall be made in writing to the city planning department, and shall contain at a minimum the
following information:
(A) A label or seal number issued by the state commissioner of licensing and regulation;
(B) A copy of the certificate of title of the manufactured home;
(C) The name, address, and telephone of the owner and installer; and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 57/418
(D) The address of the proposed location of installation.
(2) The application shall be granted or denied by the planning department no later than 45 days
from receipt thereafter.
(3) If denied, an employee of the planning department shall state in writing the reasons for denial
of the permit, which may include any of the following:
(A) Lacking a seal or label as defined herein;
(B) Plumbing deficiencies;
(C) Electrical deficiencies;
(D) Air conditioning or mechanical deficiencies;
(E) Proposed location not approved;
(F) Failure to comply with off-street parking requirements; and
(G) Tie-down plans missing.
(b) The owner of the park or manufactured home, or the installer, shall, prior to transporting or placing a
manufactured home within the city limits, apply for and receive an installation permit.
(c) Inspections required by all building codes of the city shall be concluded as a condition of approval, and
permits shall be issued only upon full compliance with the requirements of those codes.
(d) All manufactured housing shall be installed in compliance with the standards, rules, or regulations of the
city's planning department and state law. If the installation provisions of this section are preempted by state law,
pending express approval by the state commissioner of licensing and regulation of installation standards which
have been recommended by the city's planning staff, all manufactured housing shall be installed in compliance
with the standards, rules, regulations, or administrative orders of the state commissioner of licensing and
regulation.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.05)
(e) There is hereby imposed a fee in the amount as established in the fee schedule in chapter one of this code
for the pre-installation application [inspection] of a HUD-code manufactured home, which shall be paid to the
city before a HUD-code manufactured home is brought to or placed within the city limits. The application fee
shall be exclusive of all standard inspection fees imposed by the city's building codes. (1999 Unified General
Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.05; Ordinance adopting Code)
(f) In addition, there shall be a separate fee charged on an hourly basis for inspections which require more
than one hour. The person applying for the inspection shall also be charged for the actual cost of travel for
representatives of the city to and from the place of inspection. In this connection, the city manager is charged
with the responsibility to adopt and maintain a schedule of reasonable fees and charges.
(g) Subsection (e) of this section shall not apply if the manufactured home has affixed to it the appropriate
seal, label or decal required by the state commissioner of licensing and regulation and the requirements of
subsection (a) of this section have been satisfied. The requirements of subsections (b) through (d) of this section
shall be imposed in all cases.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.05)
Sec. 3.04.009 Water, sewer and electrical systems
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 58/418
All manufactured homes are to be properly connected to water, sewer, and electrical systems approved by the
city. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. V, sec. 5.00.)
Sec. 3.04.010 Fuel supply and storage
From the effective date of this code, the following shall apply:
(1) Bottled gas for cooking purposes shall not be used at individual manufactured home or travel
trailer lots unless the containers are properly connected by copper or other suitable metallic tubing.
(2) Bottled gas cylinders shall be securely fastened in place.
(3) No cylinder containing bottled gas shall be located in a manufactured home or travel trailer or
within five feet of a door.
(4) State and local regulations applicable to the handling of bottled gas and fuel oil must be
followed.
(5) Bottled gas shall not be used by manufactured homes in a manufactured subdivision or by
mobile homes in a nonconforming use.
(6) Bottles must be removed from a trailer if natural gas is available.
(7) In a manufactured home or travel trailer subdivision, natural gas piping systems shall be
installed underground and maintained in accordance with applicable codes and regulations governing
such system.
(8) Each manufactured home and travel trailer space provided with piped gas shall have a cap on
the outlet when not in accordance with the city plumbing code, as applicable.
(9) Liquefied petroleum gas systems shall be installed only if an available natural gas system is
more than one thousand (1000) feet from the mobile home park. The liquefied petroleum gas systems
shall be maintained in accordance with applicable codes of city governing such systems and
regulations of the state railroad commission pertaining thereto.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. V, sec. 5.01)
Sec. 3.04.011 Alterations
(a) A person shall not in any way alter a manufactured home or travel trailer without a permit issued for that
purpose. No permit shall be issued for the alteration of a mobile home, manufactured home or travel trailer
unless it is issued for the following alterations.
(b) Awnings of canvas or metal, suitably constructed, may be attached to said mobile home, manufactured
home or travel trailer, as well as portable, prefabricated, temporary rooms, for the express purpose of increasing
mobile home or travel trailer living areas, commonly called “cabanas,” which meet the following requirements:
(1) Of metal only, fire resistive double wall, mechanical joint panels (no welded joints between
panels permitted);
(2) Strength of materials and structures to meet minimum standards of the city building code;
(3) Capable of being dismantled when moved;
(4) Such rooms shall be completely dismantled and removed from the site at the time the mobile
home, manufactured [home] or travel trailer to which it is accessory is moved;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 59/418
(5) Finish and appearance to be as near the same as possible to one manufactured or travel to
which it is necessary [the manufactured home or travel trailer to which it is accessory];
(6) The length must not exceed the length of the manufactured [home] or travel trailer to which it
is accessory; and
(7) Only one such room per mobile home, manufactured [home] or travel trailer shall be permitted.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. III, sec. 3.04)
Secs. 3.04.012–3.04.050 Reserved
Division 2. Manufactured Home and Travel Trailer Parks
Part I. In General
Secs. 3.04.051–3.04.080 Reserved
Part II. License
Sec. 3.04.081 Required
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the city any manufactured home
and/or travel trailer park unless such person shall first obtain a license as required herein. (1999 Unified General
Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.00)
Sec. 3.04.082 Fee
The annual license fee for a manufactured home and/or travel trailer park shall be $100.00 per year and shall be
payable no later than January 10th of each year. The fee for the transfer of ownership of such license, as
provided for in this division, shall be $25.00. The city commission hereby finds that the annual license fee is a
reasonable amount to cover costs of annual inspections and the maintenance of records in connection with the
park. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.01)
Sec. 3.04.083 Application; approval
(a) Application for a manufactured home and/or travel trailer park license shall be filed with the city secretary,
and upon final approval by the city commissioners the city secretary shall issue the license. Applications shall be
in writing, signed by the applicant, and shall contain the following:
(1) The name and address of the applicant;
(2) The location and legal description of the mobile home and/or travel trailer park;
(3) A complete plan of the park showing compliance with part III of this division;
(4) Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed off-site, or to be
constructed within the park;
(5) Such further information as may be requested by the city commission to enable it to determine
if the park will comply with the legal requirements of these regulations.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 60/418
(b) The application and all accompanying plans and specifications shall be filed in triplicate. The city's
planning and zoning commission shall review the proposed plans and specifications for compliance with the
provisions of these regulations and the city's subdivision regulations set out in chapter 3 of the development
code. For purposes of the subdivision regulations, the park may be considered a “one-lot” subdivision. The
planning and zoning commission shall then make a report to the city commission concerning such applicant and
include therein their recommendations relative to the approval of the plat. If the park will be in compliance with
all provisions of this division and all other applicable regulations or statutes, the city commission may approve
the plat contingent upon the completion of the park according to the plans and specifications submitted with the
application. Approval of the plat and the plans shall not be considered a waiver of the application of the city's
building codes to all construction. The city commission shall have authority, in its discretion, to grant variances
and deviations from the provisions of these regulations in cases in which a strict application of these regulations
would cause undue hardship.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.02)
Sec. 3.04.084 Issuance
Upon completion of development of the park, the planning director shall make a site visit and shall proceed to
document violations of these regulations, if any, and recommend revocation of the application, or, upon
compliance, recommend immediate issuance of a license to operate a park. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7,
art. I, div. II, sec. 2.03)
Sec. 3.04.085 Revocation
The city commission may revoke any license issued hereunder for violations. However, before said license may
be temporarily suspended or revoked, the city commission shall give thirty (30) days' notice to the holder of the
license of proposed revocation and hold a hearing thereon. A revocation shall be based on specific findings of
fact. A revoked license may be reissued if the reasons found for said revocation have been corrected. (1999
Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.04)
Sec. 3.04.086 Transfer; duration
Upon application for a transfer of the license, the city commission may issue a transfer upon payment of a
transfer fee. Such original license and transfer may be granted at any time during the year and shall expire at the
end of the year, unless previously revoked or terminated. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec.
2.05)
Secs. 3.04.087–3.04.120 Reserved
Part III. Design and Operation
Sec. 3.04.121 Site and lot requirements
The manufactured home and/or travel trailer park shall conform to the following requirements:
(1) General site requirements. The plat shall generally conform to the requirements of the
subdivision regulations. In addition to placement in an authorized zone pursuant to the zoning
regulations, no park shall be approved unless all access to the park is from a primary arterial or
secondary thoroughfare.
(2) Drainage. The park shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to insure rapid
drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 61/418
(3) Minimum area. The minimum width and/or depth of the mobile home park shall be two
hundred sixty-five (265) feet, and the minimum total area shall be four (4) acres.
(4) Lot size. There shall be no minimum lot area for a manufactured home or travel trailer site in a
manufactured home park or travel trailer park, except that manufactured homes or travel trailers shall
be so harbored on each space so that there shall be at least a twelve-foot unobstructed clearance
between mobile homes or travel trailers parked end to end and at least a twenty-foot clearance
between mobile homes or travel trailers parked side to side. The planning director shall recommend
minimum size lots and designs in each specific case.
(5) Interior access drives. All manufactured home and/or travel trailer lots shall abut upon an
unobstructed interior access drive of not less than twenty-five (25) feet in width, which shall have
unobstructed access to a public street, alley or other thoroughfare. If this minimum requirement is
used, no parking shall be allowed on an interior access drive at any time. All interior access drives
shall be hard surfaced, well-marked in the daytime, and lighted at night. Their construction shall
comply with subdivision regulations in the development code and street improvement policies of the
city.
(6) Sidewalks. Sidewalks not less than two (2) feet wide shall be provided from the mobile home
and/or travel trailer lots to the service buildings and along all interior access drives. The sidewalks
shall be hard-surfaced (concrete or asphalt), well marked in the daytime and lighted at night. When
clearly designated, sidewalks may be contiguous with interior access drives.
(7) Recreation area. Unless the city's subdivision [regulation] otherwise provides, a minimum of
five (5) percent of the gross land area of the manufactured home park, travel trailer park or mobile
home subdivision shall be set aside for a recreation area.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. III. sec. 3.00)
Sec. 3.04.122 Distance of park boundary from residential buildings outside park
Each boundary of the park must be at least one hundred (100) feet from any permanent residential building
located outside the park. This provision shall not apply to manufactured home and/or travel trailer parks already
in existence and in operation at the time of the passage of this code, and such existing and operating parks shall
be treated as a nonconforming use insofar as these requirements are concerned. (1999 Unified General Code, ch.
7, art. I, div. III, sec. 3.01)
Sec. 3.04.123 Design standards; conversion to manufactured home subdivision
(a) Access. Access to the manufactured home or trailer park shall be from an arterial highway or secondary
thoroughfare. The number and location of interior access drives shall be controlled for traffic safety and
protection of surrounding properties, and no mobile home or trailer space shall be designated for direct access to
a street outside the boundaries of the manufactured home or trailer park.
(b) Landscaped strip. Manufactured home parks and travel trailer parks shall be surrounded by a landscaped
strip of open space a minimum of ten (10) feet wide along the street frontage with an arterial highway or
secondary thoroughfare and ten (10) feet wide along all other property lines or street frontage.
(c) Design and construction of internal streets. The city commission may impose greater requirements for
internal streets. The city commission shall take into consideration access to garbage collection, fire protection,
and utility vehicles, and the projected traffic. All internal streets shall be constructed to specifications established
by the city in its subdivision regulations, and shall be maintained by the owner or agent free of cracks, holes, and
other hazards.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 62/418
(d) “No parking” signs. On all sections of internal streets on which parking is prohibited, the owner or agent
shall erect metal signs prohibiting parking. The sign type, size, and height and location shall be approved by the
public works director prior to installation.
(e) Additional requirements for internal streets. Internal streets and interior access driveways, “no-parking”
area signs, street lighting, and street name signs shall be privately owned, built, and maintained. Streets shall be
designed for safe and convenient access to all spaces and to facilities for common use of park residents. Internal
streets and interior access driveways shall be kept open and free of obstruction in order that police and fire
vehicles may have access to any areas of the mobile home or travel trailer park. The police department shall be
authorized to issue citations for violation of provisions and to remove and impound offending vehicles.
(f) Water supply, sewers, fire protection, refuse collection and sanitary facilities. Proper provision shall be
made for public water supply, sanitary sewers, fire protection, refuse collection, and laundry, toilet and bathing
facilities, and all such provisions shall be in full compliance with the department of public works and/or
department of state health services.
(g) Conversion to manufactured home subdivision. A manufactured home park and/or travel trailer park may
be converted to a manufactured home subdivision provided it is replatted and that all conditions pertaining to the
platting of subdivisions and regulations are met.
(h) Lighting. Outside lighting shall be erected in such a manner that it not be detrimental to or project onto
adjacent properties.
(i) Paving or ground cover. Except as prohibited by city drainage policies, exposed ground surfaces in all parts
of every mobile home park shall be paved, covered with stone screening or other solid material, or protected
with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating dust.
(j) Applicability to existing parks. The provisions of subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section shall not apply
to mobile home or trailer parks in existence and operation in compliance with existing regulations and laws at
the time of approval and [such parks] shall be treated as nonconforming uses.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. III, sec. 3.02)
Sec. 3.04.124 Maintenance; screening
(a) Every person owning or operating a manufactured home and/or travel trailer park shall maintain such park,
and any facilities and fixtures, in sanitary condition and shall maintain said equipment in a state of good repair.
(b) Each manufactured home park and travel trailer park shall be screened by natural growth with landscaping
or fencing a minimum of four (4) feet in height along its boundary line.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. III, sec. 3.03)
Sec. 3.04.125 Office building; records
Each manufactured home and/or travel trailer park shall be provided with a building to be known as the office in
which shall be kept copies of all records pertaining to the tenants and users [and such records] shall be available
for inspection by the city upon reasonable request. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. III, sec. 3.05)
Sec. 3.04.126 Park rules; duties of manager
It shall be the duty of the owner or his agent, representative or manager to prescribe rules and regulations for the
management of the park, which shall be made available to the city upon reasonable request. In addition thereto,
it shall be the duty of the owner or his agent, representative or manager to comply strictly with the following:
(1) Provide for regular inspection of the water and sanitary conveniences;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 63/418
(2) Provide for the collection and removal of garbage and other waste material;
(3) Prohibit the placing or storage of unsightly material or vehicles of any kind.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. IV, sec. 4.00)
Sec. 3.04.127 Off-street parking
Off-street parking requirements shall apply to manufactured home and travel trailer parks, except that
congregate parking spaces shall be permitted as an option to the requirement that each residential space be
provided separate parking space. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.06)
Sec. 3.04.128 Registration of manufactured homes and travel trailers
(a) The city secretary may designate manufactured home and travel trailer park owners or operators as
registrars for purpose of the registration provisions of these regulations.
(b) The registrar shall, on or before January 10th of each year, register all manufactured homes and travel
trailers within the park and file the register with the city secretary.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 7, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.07)
ARTICLE 3.05 SIGNS*
Sec. 3.05.001 Purpose
(a) The purpose of this article is to establish reasonable regulations for all exterior signs and sign structures
within the incorporated limits of the city and billboard signs within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ),
in order to:
(1) Balance the right of individuals to identify businesses and convey messages with the right of
the public to be protected against the unrestricted proliferation of signs;
(2) Protect the public, health, safety and welfare;
(3) Reduce traffic hazards; and
(4) Provide for an aesthetically pleasing community.
(b) Any sign which was not lawfully existing at the time of adoption of this article shall not become or be
made legal solely by adoption of this article. By the passage of this article, no presently illegal sign shall be
deemed to have been legalized.
(Ordinance 2002-020, sec. 1.00, adopted 12/10/02)
Sec. 3.05.002 Definitions
Except where the context clearly indicates to the contrary, the following words and phrases shall have the
indicated meaning when used in this article:
Animated sign. A sign that contains animated, scrolling or moving images or text. (Ordinance 08-04-A adopted
5/31/08)
Apartment or mobile home park identification sign. A permanent on-premises sign for the identification of an
apartment building, housing complex, or mobile home park.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 64/418
Apartment or mobile home park information sign. A sign providing direction for access or parking of vehicle(s)
or direction to the office or the manager of the project, and may include public safety signs such as fire lane and
parking regulations.
Banner. A temporary sign composed of lightweight, flexible material on which letters, symbols or pictures are
painted or printed.
Billboard. An off-premises sign with a sign area exceeding 400 square feet.
Building frontage. The length of a building wall which faces a street.
Canopy. A permanent roof-like shelter extending from part or all of a building or independent of a building,
including any rigid material, cloth or fabric supported by a structural frame.
Canopy sign. A sign that is permanently affixed to a canopy by paint, glue, sewing, or any other type of
nonstructural type of attachment.
Central business district. An area within the city bordered by the following streets: Expressway 83, Wyoming
Avenue, Eighth Street and San Antonio Avenue.
Construction sign. An on-premises sign, which may be erected for a limited time as defined under section
3.05.009(2), identifying any or all of the property owners, engineers, architects, mortgagees or other participants
in the construction or improvement of the premises.
Development sign. An on-premises sign, which may be erected for a limited time as defined under section
3.05.011(6)(F), identifying and promoting one or more developments, projects or buildings proposed or
currently under construction.
Dilapidated or deteriorated condition. Any sign where:
(1) The message or wording can no longer be clearly read;
(2) The structural support or frame members are visibly bent, broken, dented, or torn;
(3) The sign face is visibly cracked or, in the case of wood and similar products, splintered in such
a way as to constitute an unsightly or harmful condition;
(4) The sign or its elements are twisted or leaning or at angles other than those at which it was
originally erected (such as may result from being blown or the failure of a structural support); or
(5) The sign or its elements are not in compliance with the requirements of the current electrical
code and/or the building code of the city.
Directional sign. A sign which contains only information designed to direct pedestrian or vehicular traffic to the
location of a facility on the property on which the sign is located. Such signs may include, but are not limited to,
arrows, words or logos. No goods or services for sale may be listed on a directional sign.
Double-faced sign. Any two adjacent signs on a single structure or separate structures with both faces oriented in
the same direction and not more than 10 feet apart at the nearest point between the two faces. May be referred to
as a side-by-side or stacked sign.
(Ordinance 2002-020, sec. 2.00, adopted 12/10/02)
Electronic variable message sign. A sign, display or device that changes its message, copy or image by
electronic or mechanical processes, including any sign which permits light to be intermittently turned on and off
or changed in color or intensity. Electronic variable message signs shall not include signs erected by the city,
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 65/418
county, state or federal government, functioning as a traffic-control device, and included in the Manual on
Uniform Traffic-control Devices or signs that display only time and temperature. (Ordinance 08-04-A adopted
5/31/08)
Flag. A sign made of cloth, bunting or similar material, often attached to a pole, with specific colors, patterns, or
symbolic devices, used as a national, state or local symbol, or to indicate membership in an organization. The
term “flag” shall also include any such display placed for decorative purposes only, with no commercial logo or
advertising message.
Freestanding sign. A sign which is attached to or a part of a completely self-supporting structure such as a frame
or one or more poles which is not attached to any building or any other structure and which is permanently
affixed to the ground.
Gasoline price sign. An on-premises sign with changeable copy letters and numbers or an electronic display
without movement affixed to a gasoline pump canopy or its supports or a freestanding sign with the intent to
display the current price of motor fuels.
General business sign. An on-premises sign which identifies a business or which advertises or promotes a
commodity or service offered on the premises where such sign is located.
Government sign. A sign indicating public works projects, public services or other programs or activities
conducted by any governmental agency.
Ground sign. Any permanent sign which is affixed to the ground with a maximum height not to exceed 48
inches above adjacent grade.
Incidental sign. A sign, generally informational, that has a purpose secondary to the use of the lot on which it is
located, such as “no parking,” “entrance,” “loading only,” “telephone,” an address, and other such directives.
Institutional identification sign. A permanent on-premises sign for the identification of a public or private
school, university, church, or hospital or other similar use.
Institutional information sign. A sign erected on the premises of the institution to provide information as to the
programs and services of the institution or to provide direction for access, parking of vehicles or guidance to
various elements or units or to provide public safety information.
Logo. An identifying symbol used for advertising purposes, which may or may not be a registered trademark or
service mark of the entity identified.
Menu board. A sign displaying the menu for drive-up window service.
Monument sign. A permanent sign with a display surface that is an integral part of the support structure. Any
ground sign exceeding four feet in height or any pole sign with less than nine feet of ground clearance shall be
considered a monument sign.
Nameplate sign. An on-premises sign showing only the name and/or address of the occupant.
Noncommercial message sign. A sign conveying a civic, political, religious, seasonal or personal message, or a
regulatory message or warning.
Office identification sign. An on-premises sign which identifies an office building or any or all of the owners,
occupants or tenants of an office building and the services related thereto.
Off-premises sign. A sign which advertises or directs attention to a business, product, service, or activity which
is not usually available on the premises where the sign is located.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 66/418
On-premises sign. A sign which advertises or directs attention to a business, product, service or activity which is
usually available on the premises where the sign is located.
Pennant. A temporary sign made of lightweight material which tapers to a point, hung individually or in a series,
with or without a logo or an advertising message printed or painted on it.
Pole sign. A permanent sign with a display surface that is attached to a completely self-supporting structure
which has at least nine feet of ground clearance.
Political sign. A temporary sign announcing or supporting political candidates or issues in connection with any
national, state or local election.
Portable sign. A temporary sign which is designed to permit removal and reuse, and which includes but is not
limited to signs converted to A- or T-frames and signs mounted on a trailer, wheeled carrier, motorized and
nonmotorized vehicle, or other portable structure. The term “portable sign” shall specifically include an outdoor
advertising display, such as a banner, located in or on a vehicle, except where:
(1) Such a sign merely identifies the vehicle as belonging to such business by displaying the name,
address and/or telephone number of such business and/or identifies the type of product or service
offered by such business;
(2) The primary use of such vehicle is for the daily transportation of products or the delivery of
services in connection with such business; and
(3) Such vehicle is currently licensed and inspected in the state and is in operable condition.
However, if such vehicle remains parked for longer than 48 consecutive hours on the same lot, it shall be
deemed a portable sign.
Projecting sign. A sign which is attached or affixed to a building, wall or structure other than a pole and which
extends more than 15 inches from such wall or structure. Such signs must provide a minimum vertical clearance
of nine feet.
Reader board. An on-premises sign announcing events or identifying products and services offered, including
cinema signs, which is oriented to a street, the message of which is periodically or continuously changed through
manual or electronic means. “Reader board sign” does not include time-temperature devices.
Real estate sign. A temporary sign pertaining to the sale, rental or lease of the premises, or a portion of the
premises, on which the sign is located.
Roof sign. A sign erected or painted upon or above the roof of a building.
Setback. The distance measured from a property line to the closest point of the sign or its supporting structure.
Shopping and/or office center. A group of four or more retail and office establishments which is planned and
developed as a business center with common access and parking.
Sign. Any structure, object, device, display or advertising artwork, situated outdoors or in a window, visible
from a public or private street or alley, which is used entirely or in part to advertise, display, direct or attract
attention to an object, person, institution, organization, business, product, service, event or location by any
means, including words, letters, figures, designs, logos, fixtures, colors, illumination or projected images.
Sign area. The entire area within a single continuous perimeter enclosing the actual message or display area of a
sign, and shall include the border and trim, but excluding supports.

https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 67/418
Sign face. That portion of the sign that is or can be used to identify, display, advertise, or communicate
information, or for a visual representation which attracts or intends to attract the attention of the public for any
purpose.
Sign height. The vertical distance between the highest point of the sign or its supporting structure and the natural
grade directly below the sign.
Sign structure. Any structure which is designed specifically for the purpose of supporting a sign, has supported
or is capable of supporting a sign. This definition shall include any decorative covers, braces, wires, supports, or
components attached to or placed around the sign structure.
Snipe or bandit sign. A sign which is tacked, nailed, posted, pasted, glued, or otherwise attached to trees, stakes,
fences, or other like objects, the advertising matter of which is not applicable to the present use of the premises
on which the sign is located.
Spectacular sign. Any sign that rotates, oscillates, is animated, contains any moving parts, or contains flashing
lights, including lights flashing in sequence to simulate movement. A reader board shall not be considered a
spectacular sign.
Sponsor panel. A portion of a sign displaying the name of a product, service or company offering goods or
services on-site or having a promotional relationship for events occurring on the premises.
Streamers. A temporary display made of lightweight, flexible materials, consisting of long, narrow, wavy strips
hung individually or in a series, with or without a logo or advertising message printed or painted on them.
Street frontage. The length of the property line of a lot or tract immediately adjacent to a public or private street,
measured in feet.
Subdivision identification sign. An identification sign at the main entrance or entrances to a residential
subdivision or planned development project.
Temporary sign. A sign not permanently affixed to the ground or to a building or other structure.
Time-temperature sign. An electronic or mechanical device which shows time and/or temperature but contains
no business identification or advertising.
Visibility clearance areas. Triangular-shaped areas which are located at the intersection of streets, or streets and
alley rights-of-way, and the intersection of streets and driveways.
V-type sign. A sign structure composed of two signs with the faces oriented in opposite directions and in the
general shape of the letter “V,” provided, however, that only one face can be viewed from any one direction from
any public street, and with a maximum angle between the faces of 60 degrees.
Wall sign. A permanent sign which is attached directly to a building surface, including window areas
(translucent areas which are visible from a street or alley), that extends not more than 15 inches from the face of
the fence or wall.
Window sign. A temporary sign placed on, affixed to, painted on or located within the frame of a transparent
opening in the wall of a building.
(Ordinance 2002-020, sec. 2.00, adopted 12/10/02)
Sec. 3.05.003 Penalty
Any person found in violation of this article shall be subject to the penalties and procedures found in chapter 1,
article II, section 4.00, in the city development code. (Ordinance 2002-020, sec. 14.00, adopted 12/10/02)
