ARTICLE 4.02 JUNKYARDS AND SALVAGE YARDS†
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.02.001 Compliance; permit required
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 99/418
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or use any property within the city limits as a junkyard unless its
operation and maintenance is conducted in accordance with these regulations and a permit to operate or maintain
such junkyard has been issued by the city. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.00; Ordinance
adopting Code)
Sec. 4.02.002 Application for permit; issuance
(a) Any person desiring to use or maintain any property within the city for the purpose of a junkyard shall
make written application to the city commission for a permit. Written application for such permit shall be filed
with the city secretary, and shall set forth:
(1) The name and address of the applicant;
(2) A legal description of the property or premises upon which the junkyard is proposed or to be
conducted; and
(3) Any other information or evidence required or desired to be submitted by the city commission
deemed necessary to properly consider the application.
(b) Upon receipt of such application, the city commission shall decide in its discretion whether to approve or
reject the application within ninety (90) days of its submittal.
(c) The city commission's discretion shall be constrained by the provisions of the city's zoning regulations,
and where any provision of this regulation conflicts with any provision of the zoning regulations, the provisions
of the zoning regulations shall prevail.
(d) Any application which is not expressly rejected within ninety (90) days shall be deemed approved.
(e) If the city commission approves the application, the city secretary shall issue a permit to the applicant
upon the payment of the permit fee.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.01)
Sec. 4.02.003 Permit fee; term; revocation
(a) Before any permit is issued to operate or maintain a junkyard, the applicant shall pay an annual fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Any permit issued shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of its issuance but
may be renewed from year to year in a like manner as is provided for in the original permit.
(b) The city commission shall have the power to revoke any permit for a violation of any provisions of this
regulation, but only after notice has been given to the record owner(s) and a hearing held not less than ten (10)
days nor more than sixty (60) days after the service of such notice.
(c) The notice shall specify the alleged violations and the dates of the violations and shall state with
particularity the facts and identify witnesses who can testify with respect to the violations.
(d) A revocation of a permit shall be authorized only upon repeated knowing violations.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. I, sec. 1.02)
Sec. 4.02.004 Location
All junkyards shall be restricted to industrially zoned properties or districts of the city. Those junkyards in
operation prior to the effective date of this article shall be allowed to continue to operate even if located in
another zoning district, subject, however, to the permit requirements. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I,
div. I, sec. 1.03)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 100/418
Secs. 4.02.005–4.02.040 Reserved
Division 2. Operation
Sec. 4.02.041 Violations
Violations hereof shall be punished by a fine as set out in the code. A violation of a non-penal regulation such as
the regulation of junkyards does not require a state of mind that rises to that of criminal intent. Therefore, an
owner or operator of a junkyard will violate the provisions hereof if a condition exists on the property which is
prohibited, whether or not he or she knew the condition existed, or knew that it was prohibited. (1999 Unified
General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.12)
Sec. 4.02.042 Contents to be kept in orderly condition
The junk within the premises of a junkyard shall be kept in an orderly arrangement so as to allow sufficient
space for an individual to walk among junk and inspect the premises and to permit easy access to all areas for
firefighting purposes. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.00)
Sec. 4.02.043 Inspections
All junkyards shall permit inspection by law enforcement officials, health department representatives, fire
department officials and building inspectors of the city. Such inspections shall be for the purpose of ascertaining
whether any health, safety or sanitary violations exist and to assist in locating stolen or lost property. (1999
Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.01)
Sec. 4.02.044 Vehicles and machinery to be drained of inflammable liquids
It is the duty of the owner(s) of the junkyards to drain all inflammable liquids and oils from the automobiles,
trucks, tractors, equipment or machinery of any kind which is kept within the premises. (1999 Unified General
Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.02)
Sec. 4.02.045 Screening fence
(a) The property and premises of such junkyards shall be enclosed by a fence at least eight feet (8') in height,
measured from ground level, and constructed of material which obscures the view. Said fence shall be kept in
good repair at all times, and no junk of any character, or parts or machinery of any kind, shall be allowed to
remain outside of such fence.
(b) Such fence enclosing the junkyard shall not be used for bill postings or for other advertising purposes,
except a space not larger than fifty (50) square feet which may be used for the advertisement of the junkyard, if
not in violation of the city's zoning or sign regulations.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.03)
Sec. 4.02.046 Standing water
It shall be unlawful to allow water to stand in any place on the premises, including the contents of the junkyard,
in such manner as to afford a breeding place for mosquitoes or create other health hazards. (1999 Unified
General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.04)
Sec. 4.02.047 Weeds
It shall be unlawful to keep weeds and other uncultivated growth on the premises, other than trees, shrubs and
bushes. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.05)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 101/418
Sec. 4.02.048 Garbage or other waste
It shall be unlawful to keep garbage or other waste on the premises. It shall be unlawful to keep refuse of any
kind on the premises, unless such refuse is defined as junk. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec.
2.07)
Sec. 4.02.049 Burning
(a) It shall be unlawful for any owner of a junkyard to burn or permit the burning of rubbish, garbage, trash,
rubber products, hydrocarbons, motor vehicles or parts, or other junk within the confines of the junkyard.
(b) It shall be rebuttably presumed, upon the proof of burning, that the owner of the junkyard has carelessly
permitted the burning.
(1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.08)
Sec. 4.02.050 Storage of junk
It shall be unlawful for any junk to rest upon or protrude over any fence or screen, public street, right-of-way,
walkway, easement, or curb or to become scattered or blown off the premises. The owner(s) shall not allow junk
to be stored at a height exceeding the height of the fence enclosing the premises. (1999 Unified General Code,
ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.09)
Sec. 4.02.051 Dismantling of appliances and other junk
All junk, including but not limited to refrigerators, stoves, washing machines and dryers, shall be inoperable in
such a manner to prevent entrapment of children. All refrigerators and freezers not stored in a lockable structure
shall have the doors removed. All junk stored or accumulated shall be dismantled so that the junk does not
constitute a public safety hazard. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.10)
Sec. 4.02.052 Combustible or flammable material
It shall be unlawful for combustible or flammable material of any kind, not necessary or integral to the operation
of the junkyard business, to be kept on the premises. (1999 Unified General Code, ch. 6, art. I, div. II, sec. 2.11)
ARTICLE 4.03 GARAGE SALES AND FLEA MARKETS
Sec. 4.03.001 Definitions
Business. An activity of or caused by a person for the purpose of a direct or indirect gain, benefit, or advantage.
Flea markets. The temporary collection, storage, display and sale of new and used goods by more than one
vendor, peddler, canvasser or solicitor in vehicles, tents, and other temporary structures such as awnings of
canvas or other materials on improved lots.
Garage sale. A sale of new or used merchandise from any residence in any residential zone classification.
Owner or occupant. Any person owning or renting or leasing or subleasing property in any residential zone
classification.
Sale or purchase. Any of the following when done or performed for consideration:
(1) A transfer of title or possession of tangible personal property or the segregation of tangible
personal property in contemplation of a transfer of its title or possession.
(2) The exchange, lease, or rental of tangible personal property.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 102/418
(3) The performance of a taxable service.
(4) The production, fabrication, processing, printing, or imprinting of tangible personal property
for consumers who directly or indirectly furnish the materials used in the production, fabrication,
processing, printing or imprinting.
(5) The furnishing and distribution of tangible personal property by a social club of fraternal
organization to anyone.
(6) The furnishing, preparation or service of foods, meals or drinks.
Seller and retailer. Includes:
(1) A person in the business of making sales at auction of tangible personal property owned by the
person or by another;
(2) A person who makes more than four sales of taxable items during a 12-month period; and
(3) A person regarded by the comptroller as a seller or retailer under section 151.024 of the Texas
Tax Code.
Seller or retailer. A person engaged in the business of making sales of taxable items of a kind the receipts from
the sale of which are included in the measure of the sales and or use tax imposed by chapter 151 of the Texas
Tax Code.
Unimproved lot. A lot lacking a building constructed after issuance of a building permit or lacking of any of the
utilities such as plumbing or electricity in compliance with the city's building plumbing and electrical permits.
Sec. 4.03.002 Permit required
(a) The owner or occupant of a house conducting a garage sale in any residential zone classified as such by the
city's zoning ordinance shall first obtain a permit from the planning department of the city, the cost of which
shall be ten and no/100 dollars ($10.00).
(b) It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of such premises or any other person to conduct thereon a
garage or porch sale without first having obtained a permit as herein required.
(c) Up to four (4) garage sale permits shall be issued per household or apartment in one calendar year.
(d) There shall be a 90-day minimum time separation between garage sale permits issued by the city.
(e) Anyone violating this section shall, upon conviction, be fined in an amount not less than twenty-five and
no/100 dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred and no/100 dollars ($200.00).
Sec. 4.03.003 Collection; storing; display and sale of goods in open and unimproved property
(a) The collection, storing, display and sale of goads in open and unimproved lots in the city is hereby
prohibited.
(b) A person commits an offense if he/she collects, stores, displays or sells goods in open and unimproved lots
in the city.
(c) An offense under this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00).
Sec. 4.03.004 Use of street; street right-of-way or sidewalk as place of business
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 103/418
(a) It is unlawful for any person to use any street, street right-of-way, sidewalk, plaza or other public place
within the city as a place of business.
(b) A person commits an offense if he/she uses any street, sidewalk, plaza or other public place within the city
as a place of business are herein prohibited.
(c) An offense under this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00).
Sec. 4.03.005 Flea markets
(a) The city commission, in the exercise of its discretion, shall grant special use permits for flea markets
taking into consideration the health, welfare and safety of the public, but no permit shall be issued for a period of
more than one (1) year.
(b) It shall be unlawful for a person to conduct a flea market within the corporate limits without first having
obtained a special use permit.
(c) An offense under this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) per day.
(d) Persons applying for a special use permit for a flea market must show the following:
(1) That the proposed area for the flea market has a paved parking area sufficient to accommodate
the needs of the flea market without obstructing surrounding roadways and traffic;
(2) That the noise level of the flea market will be controlled and will not be a nuisance to the
surrounding area; and
(3) That there are electrical, sanitation and plumbing facilities that are accessible to the flea market
and sufficient to meet the needs of the flea market clientele.
(e) Flea markets shall only be allowed in the following areas:
(1) Where the tract of land to be used for the flea market abuts a major thoroughfare being a
principal arterial or higher-classified roadway as shown in the adopted county thoroughfare plan.
(2) Where there are no residences or dwelling units within 500 feet.
(Ordinance 14-18 adopted 8/12/14)
ARTICLE 4.04 WRECKER BUSINESSES*
Sec. 4.04.001 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in
this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Motor vehicle. Every vehicle which is self-propelled.
Owner. Any person who holds the legal title of a motor vehicle, who has the legal right of possession of a motor
vehicle or who has the legal right to such vehicle.
Vehicle. Every device in or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public
highway, except devices moved only by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, and
includes, but is not limited to, trailers and semitrailers.
Wrecker. Any motor vehicle used for the purpose of towing or removing disabled or wrecked vehicles.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 104/418
Wrecker business. The business of towing or removing vehicles on the public streets when the towing is done to
remove a wrecked or disabled vehicle from the scene of a collision at the instance or request of the owner of the
vehicle or the police department or fire department, regardless of whether the purpose of the towing is to
remove, repair, wreck, store, trade or purchase such vehicle, or to remove a vehicle from an unlawfully parked
position at the instance or request of the police department or fire department.
Wrecker company. Any person or company engaged in the wrecker business.
Wrecker rotation list. The rotation list of companies prepared and used as provided in section 4.04.013.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 1.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.002 Penalty; additional remedies
(a) Any owner of a wrecker company, agent or employee of a wrecker company, driver or operator of a
wrecker found guilty of violating this article or any of its provisions on complaint filed in municipal court or in
any other court of competent jurisdiction shall, upon a finding of guilty, be fined as provided in section 1.01.009
of this code.
(b) In addition to the penal remedy provided for in this section, the city shall be entitled to injunctive or other
civil remedy in any court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the laws of the state.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 16.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.003 Purpose
The operation of emergency wreckers and emergency wrecker service in the city requires regulation in order to
avoid competitive speeding by wreckers to the scene of accidents and collisions, and is necessary in order to
avoid traffic hazards and to minimize the danger of injury to persons and damage to property. (Ordinance 03-
006, sec. 2.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.004 Application for permit and certificate
Every person desiring to engage in the wrecker business in the city shall make application, in writing, on a form
provided for that purpose, to the chief of police for a permit to engage in the wrecker business and for a safety
and insurance compliance certificate for each wrecker proposed to be operated, and such application shall
contain the name, address, telephone number, the number and types of wrecker equipment to be operated, the
true owner of the company concerned, and a statement that the applicant does or does not desire to appear on the
wrecker rotation list. Every application, when filed, shall be sworn to by the applicant. (Ordinance 03-006, sec.
3.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.005 Standards for issuance of permit and certificate; fees
The chief of police, or his representative, shall issue a permit to engage in the wrecker business to all applicants
complying with the provisions of this article and shall issue a permit and safety and insurance compliance
certificate for all wreckers of such applicants so complying. No permit authorizing the operation of a wrecker
business and no safety and insurance compliance certificate authorizing the operation of a wrecker on the streets
of the city shall be issued unless the following requirements are met:
(1) Wrecker equipment and impound area. Every wrecker proposed to be used by the applicant
shall comply with the following minimum safety requirements:
(A) Each wrecker shall be not less than three-quarters ton in size and shall be equipped with
booster brakes.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 105/418
(B) Each wrecker shall be equipped with a power winch line and boom with a factory-rated
lift capacity of not less than 5,000 pounds single line capacity.
(C) Each wrecker shall carry as standard equipment tow bars, or roller bars, safety chains, a
fire extinguisher, wrecking bars, and an axe. The applicant shall have dollies if needed, but they
are not required equipment for each wrecker.
(D) Each wrecker shall provide that its impoundment area, if located in the city, shall, at
minimum, meet all of the city's development and general code requirements.
(E) The impoundment area, if located outside of the city, shall be within and not exceed a
seven-mile radius from the main police station.
(2) Insurance. All wrecker services shall procure and keep in full force and effect a policy of public
liability and property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance company authorized to do
business in the state and in the standard form approved by the board of insurance commissioners of
the state, with the insured provision of such policy including the city as an insured, and the coverage
provision insuring the public from any loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by
reason of the operation of a wrecker of such company and providing that the amount of recovery on
each wrecker shall be in limits of not less than $500,000.00 for damages arising out of bodily injury
to or death of one person in any one accident, and $100,000.00 for injury to or destruction of property
in any one accident.
(3) Driver information. A list of all wrecker operators/drivers and a copy of their Texas operator's
license shall be submitted with the above insurance policies. It shall be the obligation of the wrecker
service to keep the operator/driver license information current pursuant to section 521.459
Transportation Code.
(4) Delinquent taxes. No delinquent taxes shall be due the city upon any wrecker for which such
permit or certificate is sought, and the owner thereof shall not have failed to render the amount due
for ad valorem taxation.
(5) Fees; renewal of permit.
(A) Annual fee. There is hereby imposed an annual fee of $100.00 per wrecker company.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 4.00, adopted 6/11/03)
(B) Inspection fee. There is hereby imposed an annual inspection fee of $35.00 per wrecker
unit and a government entity/law enforcement fee of $15.00 per vehicle towed. (These fees
shall be deposited, upon recovery, in the police departments account and utilized for any and all
efforts for the enforcement of this section, and general traffic safety for nonconsent tows, each
wrecker will submit payment monthly). (Ordinance 12-02, sec. I, adopted 2/28/12)
(C) Refund of fees. All fees are nonrefundable.
(D) Application for renewal. Annual renewal applications may be submitted between
November 1 and January 31 of each year. A certificate of insurance and fees shall be submitted
with the written renewal application. Regardless of when a renewal application is submitted, the
renewal permit will be from February 1 through January 31.
(E) Late fee. A late fee of $50.00 will be charged if the completed renewal permit application
if not filed or postmarked by midnight, January 31 of each year.
(6) State licenses and certificates. A copy of all licenses and/or certificates issued by the state
allowing the applicant to operate a wrecker, impound yard or vehicle storage facility shall be required
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 106/418
upon payment of annual fees per wrecker company wrecker unit.
(7) Identification on vehicles. Each wrecker shall have the wrecker company's name, address, city
where located, and telephone number of the business operating the wrecker permanently inscribed on
each side of the vehicle in letters no less than two inches high in contrasting colors. No temporary
signs of any kind will be permitted.
(8) Certification sticker. Certification shall be evidenced by a windshield sticker affixed to the
lower left side of the windshield.
(9) Duplicate certificate. A duplicate certificate will be issued upon reinspection and payment of
$25.00 reinspection fee.
(10) Revocation of certificate. A wrecker certification will be revoked for failure to meet and/or
maintain the required standards and regulations of state law and this article.
(11) Application for recertification. If a wrecker certification is revoked, an application for
recertification may be made as soon as the wrecker meets standards.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 4.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.006 Requirements for operating wrecker
Each safety and insurance compliance certificate for a wrecker vehicle shall state that such wrecker has been
inspected and approved under the direction of the department of public safety, and a current inspection sticker
shall be affixed securely to the inside of the windshield of the wrecker vehicle. No person shall operate a
wrecker on the public streets of the city unless a permit to engage in the wrecker business has been issued to the
owner of such wrecker, a safety and insurance compliance certificate has been issued to such wrecker and the
wrecker has a current state inspection sticker. No permit or safety and insurance compliance certificate shall be
transferable, and every permit and safety and insurance compliance certificate shall expire at midnight on
January 31 of the year in which the permit expires. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 5.00(1), adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.007 Grounds for suspension or revocation of permit
(a) A permit holder may have his permit suspended:
(1) For seven days for any violation of this article.
(2) For 20 days for a second or subsequent violation of this article.
(b) A permit holder may have his permit revoked:
(1) For a third or subsequent violation of this article.
(2) Causes or permits the operation of a city certified wrecker, either owned or contracted for, by
an unlicensed driver on the public roadways.
(3) Causes or permits the operation of a wrecker not certified by the city, either owned or
contracted for, on the public roadway.
(4) Fails to maintain in force the insurance required for the operation of a towing company, vehicle
storage facility or its equipment by the laws of the state.
(5) Operates the wrecker or wrecker company in any way which endangers the life or safety of any
person in any of the following ways:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 107/418
(A) The grossly negligent operation of a vehicle used by the wrecker company.
(B) Criminal assault committed by the permit holder, his agents, or employees during the
normal course of business.
(6) Submits false information on a permit application.
(7) Is convicted of a violation under this article.
(8) Is convicted of fraud or theft, as defined in the Texas Penal Code, in the conduct or operation of
the permit holder's wrecker company.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 5.00(2), (3), adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.008 Procedure for suspension or revocation of permit
(a) Upon complaint against a wrecker company or any agent or employee thereof filed by any person with the
chief of police, or upon his own motion charging a violation of any of the terms of this article or any ordinances
of the city or laws of the state regulating motor vehicles or crimes of moral turpitude or for good cause shown,
the chief of police shall immediately turn such complaints over to the city manager. The city manager, after
giving five days' notice of such complaint to such wrecker company, may hear evidence with reference to such
complaint and after such hearing may order the chief of police to revoke or suspend the permit issued under this
article for good cause shown.
(b) After the chief of police has heard the complaint for revocation or suspension of the permit of any wrecker
company, he shall make his findings and declare such findings along with the terms, if any, of any suspension of
a temporary or permanent nature. The decision of the city manager shall be reduced to writing. The wrecker
company or the complainant shall have the right to appeal the city manager's decision to the city commission.
All appeals must be filed within ten days from the date of the decision of the city manager or such appeal will be
barred and the decision of the city manager will become final and binding upon all parties. The city commission
shall set the hearing date for all appeals from the city manager under this section. After an evidentiary hearing,
the decision of the city commission shall be reduced to writing, wherein they shall make findings and declare
such findings. No appeal will lie from the decision of the city commission as it is final.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 14.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.009 Wreckers to be summoned by police or fire department
No person shall drive a wrecker to or within 100 feet of the scene or situs of an accident or collision on the
streets of the city unless such person has been called to the scene by the police department or fire department;
provided that, when it is necessary to prevent death or bodily injury to any person involved in an accident or
collision, the prohibition of this section shall be inapplicable. The owner or operator of a wrecker shall not use or
act upon any information received on the shortwave frequency of the police or fire department of the city for his
own benefit or the benefit of any other person in connection with the operation of a wrecker business unless such
owner or operator was called or summoned by the fire or police department. If any wrecker appears at the scene
of an accident or collision, the owner or operator of which was not specifically called by the fire or police
department, it shall be conclusively presumed that such owner or operator unlawfully intercepted and acted on
the information transmitted by the fire or police department on its radio frequency. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 6.00,
adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.010 Soliciting business at scene of accident prohibited
No person shall solicit in any manner, directly or indirectly, on the streets of the city, the business of towing any
vehicle which is wrecked or disabled on a public street, regardless of whether the solicitation is for the purpose
of soliciting the business of towing, removing, repairing, wrecking, storing, trading or purchasing such vehicle.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 108/418
Proof of the presence of any person engaged in the wrecker business or the presence of any wrecker or motor
vehicle owned or operated by any person engaged in the wrecker business, either as owner, operator, employee
or agent, on any public street in the city at or near the scene or situs of a wreck, accident or collision, within one
hour after the happening of a wreck, accident or collision, shall be prima facie evidence of a solicitation in
violation of this section. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 7.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.011 Intercepting communications from police or fire department radio frequency
No owner of a wrecker company, not licensed by the city, shall intercept any message emanating through the
medium of the fire or police department radio frequency or divulge or publish the existence, contents, substance,
purpose, effect or meaning of such intercepted communication; and no person, not being entitled thereto, shall
receive or assist in receiving any such message and use such message, or any information therein contained, for
his own benefit or for the benefit of another person. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 8.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.012 Selection of wrecker by vehicle owner
Wrecker selection by vehicle owner shall be limited to the city's wrecker rotation list. (Ordinance 12-02, sec. II,
adopted 2/28/12)
Sec. 4.04.013 Placement on rotation list; use of rotation list
(a) If the owner of a vehicle involved in an accident or collision is physically unable to name the wrecker
company desired or declines to name one, or if the public safety departments of the city are called relating to a
request for wrecker service, the investigating or responding officer or employee shall communicate the fact
immediately to police department headquarters for selection of a wrecker from the wrecker rotation list
maintained by the city police department as provided in this article. Any wrecker company that desires to be
placed on the city wrecker rotation list shall meet the following requirements:
(1) Have been issued a permit and safety and insurance compliance certificate in accordance with
this article.
(2) Have applied to be on such list.
(3) Maintain 24-hour wrecker service located within and not exceeding a seven-mile radius of the
city police department central office and be within a 20-minute response time to anywhere in the city.
(4) Maintain an impound yard located within and not exceeding a seven-mile radius of the city
police department central office.
(5) In addition to the minimum requirements for wreckers required in section 4.04.005, possess at
least one licensed wrecker not less than one and one-half tons in size, equipped with a poweroperated
winch, winch line and boom, with a factory-rated lifting capacity of not less than 10,000
pounds, single line capacity.
(6) In addition to the minimum requirements for wreckers required in section 4.04.005, possess at
least one licensed platform wrecker.
(7) Agree to respond to all requests for wrecker service initiated by the city.
(8) The owner or operator of the wrecker company shall immediately notify the chief of police or
his designated representative of any change in status as it relates to any insurance, certificate, or
permit or any factor that may impede its ability to comply with this article.
(9) The owner or operator of the wrecker company shall produce a monthly report by the third
Monday of each month listing the status of any and all vehicles towed for the city that are considered
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 109/418
abandoned in their lot, after proper notification has been given in accordance with Transportation
Code subchapter C, Vehicle Abandoned in Storage Facility, section 683.031.
(b) Upon receiving a communication from the city police department, the wrecker company presently on call,
or its duly authorized agent, shall tow the disabled vehicle and remove such vehicle from the public streets of the
city. On each succeeding communication of the inability or refusal of an owner to name a wrecker, the next
company on the list shall be called, and proper rotation on such list shall be on a per-call basis for each wrecker
company on the wrecker rotation list. The chief of police or his designated agent shall establish the procedures
for the rotation of wreckers on the wrecker rotation list.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 10.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.014 Police officers not to recommend wrecker service
No police officer investigating or present at the scene or situs of any wreck, accident or collision on a public
street shall, directly or indirectly, either by word, gesture, sign or otherwise, recommend to any person the name
of any particular person engaged in the wrecker service or repair business, nor shall any such police officer
influence or attempt to influence in any manner the decision of any person in choosing or selecting a wrecker or
repair service; provided that any police officer, in the exercise of his discretion as a police officer, may direct
that any vehicle, whether towed by a wrecker selected by the owner of the vehicle or from the wrecker rotation
list, shall be taken by the driver of the wrecker towing the vehicle directly to the city pound or other location
designated by such police officer and there held by the city for any lawful purpose. (Ordinance 03-006, sec.
11.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.015 Maximum rates for wreckers on rotation list
(a) Those wreckers who volunteer for rotation agree to follow the rates as set out herein as a condition of
being placed on the rotation list. The maximum rates or fees authorized to be charged for the following
enumerated wrecker services in response to a call from any employee of the city acting in his official capacity
are as follows. Any person requesting his vehicle to be removed to a garage or other area will be responsible for
the additional wrecker fee. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 12.00, adopted 6/11/03)
(1) Towing a wrecked or disabled vehicle or illegally parked vehicle: $150.00. (Ordinance 12-02,
sec. III, adopted 2/28/12)
(2) Towing away overparked vehicle from parking meter area: $35.00.
(3) Towing of disabled vehicle from high water; up to a maximum fee per hour, per wrecker:
$50.00.
(4) Rolled over or upset vehicles: $50.00.
(5) Rollover with dolly tow: $60.00.
(6) If winch required, additional for each 50 feet of pull: $20.00.
(7) (A) Waiting time over 15 minutes at the scene of an accident (per quarter hour): $7.50.
(B) Additional time required by the wrecker for extraction or rollover of vehicles for actual
working time over 30 minutes (per quarter hour): $12.50.
(8) Disconnecting transmission: $10.00.
(9) Use of dollies or other specialized equipment (no dolly fee will be allowed for flatbeds or
wheel lifts): $50.00.

(10) Towing of trucks exceeding one ton:
(A) First hour of service (minimum charge): $75.00.
(B) Additional time required to remove such vehicle (per working hour): $75.00.
(11) Towing vehicle from outside the city limits: $15.00. Plus, per mile to and from location of

(12) Pickup and delivery of vehicle to city pound:
(A) Daytime delivery: $35.00.

(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 12.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.016 Safety precautions and operation procedures; compliance with traffic laws
Each wrecker company certificate holder shall follow standard safety precautions and operation procedures
generally recognized in the wrecker business to and from and at the scene of an accident or collision and shall
comply with all traffic code ordinances of the city. Each wrecker company at the scene of an accident or
collision shall promptly remove all debris from an accident or collision occurring on the public right-of-way.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 13.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.017 Unauthorized removal of vehicles
It shall be unlawful for any person, in the operation of an automobile wrecker on the public streets and ways of
the city and not having been directed to do so by the chief of police, the parking manager of the public works
department or authorized representatives, knowingly to move, tow, haul or otherwise transport in, on or over the
public streets and ways of the city any vehicle which has been abandoned or which has been involved in a
collision and is on a public street, way or other public property. (Ordinance 03-006, sec. 15.00, adopted 6/11/03)
Sec. 4.04.018 Limit on number of companies on rotation list
(a) The number of wrecker companies on the rotation list shall be based on the annual population census, at
one wrecker company per each full 5,000 residents in population. Provided, however, the current list of 13
wrecker companies on the rotation list may be maintained until attrition has reduced the number to the maximum
established in the preceding sentence.
(b) The city planning department is hereby charged with the responsibility of determining the yearly
population of the city. Such report shall be generated within the first six months of each calendar year. Such
population report shall thereafter be approved by the board of commissioners at a regular meeting of such board.
The chief of police or his designated representative shall not increase the number of wrecker companies until
such population report has received the approval of the board of commissioners.
(Ordinance 03-006, sec. 17.00, adopted 6/11/03)

ARTICLE 4.05 TELECOMMUNICATION SERVICES*
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 4.05.001–4.05.030 Reserved
Division 2. Use and Occupancy of Right-of-Way
Sec. 4.05.031 Purpose
The purpose of this division is to:
(1) Assist in the management of the rights-of-way;
(2) Govern the use and occupancy of the rights-of-way by telecommunications service providers;
(3) Secure fair and reasonable compensation for the use and occupancy of the rights-of-way by
telecommunications service providers in a nondiscriminatory and competitively neutral manner.
(Ordinance 99-003, sec. 1.0, adopted 2/10/99)
Sec. 4.05.032 Definitions
Whenever used in this division, the following terms, as well as their singulars, plurals and possessives, shall
have the following definitions and meanings, unless the context of the sentence in which they are used indicates
otherwise:
Access line.
(1) Each switched transmission path of the transmission media within the rights-of-way extended
to the end-user customer's premises network interface within the city that allows delivery of
telecommunications service;
(2) Each loop provided as an unbundled network element to a person pursuant to an agreement
under section 252 of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996; and
(3) Each termination point of a non-switched telephone circuit consisting of transmission media
connecting specific locations identified by, and provided to, the end user for the delivery of nonswitched
telecommunications service within the city.
Cable service. “Cable service” as defined in the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended, 47
U.S.C. section 532 et seq.
Direction of the city. All ordinances, laws, rules, resolutions, and regulations of the city that are not inconsistent
with this division and that are now in force or may hereafter be passed and adopted.
Facilities. Any and all of the duct spaces, manholes, poles, conduits, underground and overhead passageways,
and other equipment, structures, plant, and appurtenances and all associated transmission media used for the
provision of telecommunications service.
Line fee. A monthly fee to be applied to each access line for the calculation of the total amount to be paid to the
city as a rights-of-way fee.
Permit holder. Any telecommunications service provider issued a permit pursuant to the terms of this division.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 112/418
Person. A natural person (an individual), corporation, company, association, partnership, firm, limited liability
company, joint venture, joint stock company or association, and other such entity.
Public utility. A public utility as that term is used in the Public Utility Regulatory Act of 1995, Tex. Utilities
Code Ann. section 11.004, including municipally owned and/or operated utilities.
Rights-of-way. All present and future public streets, avenues, highways, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards, drives,
tunnels, easements, bridges, and other such similar passageways, thoroughfares, and public ways within the city.
Rights-of-way fee. The total amount paid to the city on a quarterly basis for the use and occupancy of the rightsof-
way.
Telecommunications service. The transmittal of voice, data, images, graphics and other communications between
or among points by wire, fiber optics, or other similar facilities, as well as the rental, lease, or furnishing of the
facilities to accomplish such transmittal, but does not include transmissions for long distance purposes
(interLATA and intraLATA) or any “wireless service” as defined by law.
Telecommunications service provider. Any person that supplies telecommunications service to others within the
corporate limits of the city in exchange for money or other value.
Telecommunications utility. “Telecommunications utility” as used in the Public Utility Regulatory Act of 1995,
Tex. Utilities Code Ann. section 51.002(11).
Transmission media. Any and all of the cables, fibers, wires or other physical devices owned, maintained or
placed by a permit holder to transmit and/or receive communication signals, whether analog, digital or of other
characteristics, and whether for voice, data or other purposes.
Use and occupancy. The permit holder's acquisition, installation, construction, reconstruction, maintenance,
repair, control, or operation of any facilities within the rights-of-way for any purpose whatsoever.
(Ordinance 99-003, sec. 2.0, adopted 3/24/99)
Sec. 4.05.033 Permit required
Any person that owns, places, or maintains facilities within the rights-of-way shall first obtain a permit pursuant
to the terms of this division. Subject to the restrictions set forth herein, the city under this division shall issue
permits to telecommunications service providers for the purpose of regulating the use and occupancy of the
public rights-of-way in the city for the provision of access lines. By acceptance of the permit, the permit holder
agrees to abide by the reasonable terms of this division in all its operations within the city, including all
operations and facilities and transmission media used in whole or in part in the provision of access lines in any
newly annexed areas as specified in section 4.05.035(c) of this division. (Ordinance 99-003, sec. 3.0, adopted
3/24/99)
Sec. 4.05.034 General terms
(a) No rights agreed to in this division by the city shall be exclusive, and the city reserves the right to grant
franchises, licenses, easements or permissions to use the rights-of-way within the city to any person as the city,
in its sole discretion, may determine to be in the public interest.
(b) A permit holder is not authorized to provide cable service as a cable operator in the city under this
division, but must first obtain a franchise from the city for that purpose, under such terms and conditions as may
be required by law.
(c) The initial term of each permit issued under this division shall be three (3) years from the date of issuance,
unless terminated earlier by mutual written agreement of the city and the permit holder or pursuant to law. At the
expiration of the initial permit period, the permit shall be automatically extended for successive periods of one
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 113/418
(1) year, unless written notice of intent to terminate the permit is given not less than ninety (90) days prior to the
termination of the then-current period by the city to permit holder. When such notice is given, the permit shall
terminate at the expiration of the then-current period. The permit holder shall provide notice of the impending
automatic renewal at least 120 days prior to the end of the then-current period; provided, however, that the
permit holder's failure to provide notice shall not invalidate the automatic renewal of the ordinance.
(d) The rights granted by this division inure to the benefit of the permit holder licensed hereunder. This rights
granted by permit shall not be assigned, transferred, or sold to another by the permit holder without the express
written consent of the city. For the purposes of this section, assignment, transfer or sale means a change of
operating control of the permit holder, expressly excepting an assignment or transfer to entities that control, are
controlled by or are under common control with the permit holder. Any such consent by the city shall not be
withheld unreasonably.
(Ordinance 99-003, sec. 4.0, adopted 3/24/99)
Sec. 4.05.035 Compensation
(a) Rights-of-way fee. The permit holder shall pay to the city a rights-of-way fee that is calculated as of
month-end by applying the appropriate line fee to each access line owned, placed, or maintained by the permit
holder that is activated for use by an end user or for another telecommunications service provider that uses the
permit holder's services or facilities for the provision of telecommunications service within the city. The line fee
to be applied to each access line on a monthly basis shall be:
Access Line Monthly Fee per Access Line
Residential $0.90
Nonresidential $2.00
(b) Number of access lines. Subject to the city's agreement not to disclose this information, each permit holder
must provide annually, within a reasonable time after receipt of the city's written request, a report showing the
number of each type of access line owned or placed and maintained by the permit holder within the city that are
activated for end-user customers and other telecommunications service providers at month's end for each of the
preceding twelve (12) months. The city agrees that the report shall be used solely for the purpose of verifying
the number of the permit holder's access lines within the city that are activated for end-user customers and
telecommunications service providers. Upon written request, the permit holder shall verify the information in the
report and, upon reasonable advance notice, produce to the city and permit inspection by the city of all noncustomer-
specific records and documents reasonably calculated to verify the information. For purposes of
payment of fees for use of the rights-of-way, lines terminating at customers' premises that are billed as
“Lifeline,” “Tel-Assistance,” or other service that is required to be similarly discounted pursuant to state or
federal law or regulation for the purpose of advancing universal service to the economically disadvantaged shall
not be included in the lines upon which the fee is calculated.
(c) Annexation and disannexation. Within thirty (30) days following the date of the passage of any action
effecting the annexation of any property to or the disannexation of any property from the city's corporate
boundaries, the city agrees to furnish the permit holder written notice of the action and an accurate map of the
city's corporate boundaries showing, if available, street names and number details. For the purpose of
compensating the city under this division, a permit holder shall start including or excluding access lines within
the affected area in the permit holder's count of access lines on the effective date designated by the comptroller
